surreptitious.explanation: stealthy, taking pains not to be caught or detected
surreptitious.example: Since his mom was a light sleeper, Timmy had to tiptoe surreptitiously through the entire house, careful to not make the floors creak, until he at last was able to enjoy his plunder: a box of chocolate chip cookies.

invidious.example: At a time when many others in the office were about to be laid off, many considered Cheryl's fine clothes that day an invidious display.

dovetail.explanation: fit together tightly, as if by means of an interlocking joint
dovetail.example: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail very well.

subterfuge.explanation: something intended to misrepresent the true nature of an activity
subterfuge.example: Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.

irrefutable.example: Scientists are searching for irrefutable evidence that some form of life existed on mars at some point in its history.

obstreperous.explanation: noisily and stubbornly defiant; willfully difficult to control
obstreperous.example: When the teacher asked the obstreperous student simply to bus his tray, the student threw the entire tray on the floor, shouted an epithet, and walked out.

celerity.example: We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.

patent.example: Since the book had been through no fewer than six proof runs, the staff was shocked to see such a patent spelling mistake remaining, right in the middle of the front cover!

unpropitious.explanation: (of a circumstance) with little chance of success
unpropitious.example: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.

flippant.example: Although Sam was trying to honor Mark's sense of humor, many found it quite flippant that he wore a comic nose and glasses mask to Mark's funeral.

ossify.explanation: make rigid and set into a conventional pattern
ossify.example: Even as a young man, Bob had some bias against poor people, but during his years in social services, his bad opinions ossified into unshiftable views.

crystallize.explanation: cause to take on a definite and clear shape
crystallize.example: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize.

impetuous.explanation: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation
impetuous.example: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.

dispensation.explanation: an exemption from a rule or obligation
dispensation.example: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies.

firebrand.example: Freddie is a firebrand: every time he walks into the office, he winds up at the center of heated argument.

intimation.example: At first the hostess tried intimation, praising the benefits of cutlery; when Cecil continued eating with his hands, the hostess told him to use a fork at dinner.

immure.example: The modern supermarket experience makes many feel claustrophobic, as they are immured in walls upon walls of products.

crestfallen.example: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.

hubris.example: Bill Clinton was criticized for his hubris, since he believed he could get away with anything once in the White House.

inure.explanation: to make accustomed to something unpleasant
inure.example: Three years of Manhattan living has inured her to the sound of wailing sirens; she could probably sleep through the apocalypse.

apposite.example: For a writer with such quick wit, Jonathan Swift has a rather apposite name.

encumber.example: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

unviable.explanation: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).
unviable.example: The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.

rarefied.example: Jack's vulgar jokes were not so successful in the rarefied environment of college professors.

recrimination.example: The two brothers sat and cried, pointing fingers and making elaborate recriminations of the other's guilt

peripatetic.example: Jim always preferred a peripatetic approach to discovering a city: he felt that he could see so many more details while walking.

lacerate.explanation: deeply hurt the feelings of; distress
lacerate.example: The teacher was fired for lacerating a student who wrote a poor essay.

equitable.explanation: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience
equitable.example: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting—at least until the ice cream is gone.

spartan.explanation: unsparing and uncompromising in discipline or judgment; practicing great self-denial
spartan.example: After losing everything in a fire, Tim decided to live in spartan conditions, sleeping on the floor and owning as little furniture as possible.

unflappable.explanation: not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and composure
unflappable.example: The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.

magisterial.explanation: offensively self-assured or given to exercising unwarranted power
magisterial.example: Though she was only a third grade teacher, Ms. Martinet was magisterial in dealing with her class, lording over them like a queen.

inimitable.example: Mozart's music follows a clear pattern that, anyone could imitate, but his music gives an overall sense of effortlessness that is inimitable.

machinate.explanation: engage in plotting or enter into a conspiracy, swear together
machinate.example: The rebels met at night in an abandoned barn to machinate.

ribald.example: The speaker was famous for his ribald humor, but the high school principal asked him to keep the talk G-rated when he spoke to the student body.

incontrovertible.explanation: necessarily or demonstrably true; impossible to deny or disprove
incontrovertible.example: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.

hobble.explanation: to hold back  the progress of something
hobble.example: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.

puerile.explanation: of or characteristic of a child; displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity
puerile.example: Helen enjoyed blowing soap bubbles, but Jim regarded this as puerile, totally unworthy of a woman with a Ph.D.

nonchalant.explanation: coming across as uninterested or unconcerned; overly casual
nonchalant.example: The twenty-somethings at the coffee shop always irked Sheldon, especially the way in which they acted nonchalantly towards everything, not even caring when Sheldon once spilled his mocha on them.

tempestuous.explanation: as if driven by turbulent or conflicting emotions; highly energetic and wildly changing or fluctuating
tempestuous.example: Chuck and Kathy had always been stable and agreeable people on their own, but when they got involved, it was a tempestuous relationship.

presentiment.explanation: a feeling of evil to come
presentiment.example: On the night that Lincoln would be fatally shot, his wife had a presentiment about going to Ford's Theater, but Lincoln persuaded her that everything would be fine.

corollary.explanation: a practical consequence that follows naturally
corollary.example: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the U.S., is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.

denouement.explanation: the final resolution of the many strands of a literary or dramatic work; the outcome of a complex sequence of events
denouement.example: At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.

inviolate.example: While the literary critic subjected most of the classics to the harshest reviews, he regarded Cervantes as inviolate, and had nothing but praise for him.

puissant.example: Over the years of service, and quite to his surprise, he became a puissant advisor to the community.

untenable.explanation: (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified
untenable.example: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.

improvident.example: Marty was improvident, never putting money aside for the future but spending it on decorating the interior of his home.

asperity.example: The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.

cosset.example: The king and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.

decry.example: The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.

imperious.explanation: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy
imperious.example: Children are imperious with each other before they learn that earning someone's respect is better than demanding.

stalwart.explanation: dependable; inured to fatigue or hardships
stalwart.example: Despite all the criticism directed at the President during this scandal, Lisa has remained his stalwart supporter.
